item.title: Base Camp
item.description: Just a paint-sketch. The puffin scouts set up camp not far from the rest, just outside of Krafla in the Lava region. When they moved south tomorrow, thick native grasses and trees would give way to flower-tundras and bare hills, and by Tuesday theyâ€™d be in the heart of Lava â€” empty and extraterrestrial and volcanic. The Krafla high-energy communications tower was visible from all over the region. It provided uninterrupted radio to most of North Lava, and could relay signals through satellites.

item.title: The Race for Inefficiency â€” Veklleiâ€™s advocation of austerity, apathy, and playfulness as economic principles
item.description: This post is about the economy of Vekllei. It’s a bit of a long one. If you have any questions, just ask. Overview of the Bureau System # There are many thousands of companies busy with work in Vekllei. The vast majority of these companies are single-person shops (S.p.A., or senrouiva pettetie anaproiouya). Also common are wobbly shops, or co-operative businesses (S.q.A., or senrouiva qualitie anaproiouya). The largest of the non-bureau companies are village factories (S.

item.title: Canal Living
item.description: Atlantic Salmon was the best in the world, and Vekllei had a lot of it. Ocean-going fishing boats brought their haul to Ro, where they cruised wide postwar canals and unloaded tonnes of shiny, bright salmon into processing plants. If a new factory was built, so too was a canal or a railroad. Nothing was trucked. Fish was traded fresh in markets or turned into emulsifiers and fertiliser. The canals were worked heavily, and few fishing vessels were incorporated.

item.title: The Last Train Out of Ada
item.description: They both watched as train 416 pulled away from the platform. And that was that â€” there would be no school in the morning. That was how it worked in rural Vekllei, a million miles from the automatic trains on endless timetables. Out here, you paced life around the station. There was not much to say about this, between the two of them. Tzipora looked at Cobian and pulled a froggy smile that tried to express that it was nobodyâ€™s fault.

item.title: Winter Uniforms in Vekllei
item.description: When I paint Vekllei, I usually depict the warmer months. Hems are shorter, days are longer, and the destabilisation of the worldâ€™s climate has only benefited these arctic people. At the gift end of the Vekllei low pressure system, Scandinavian misery has become Mediterranean pleasure, with warm summers and a mild Autumn and Spring. Still, by late October, the the earth is hard with cold and the days are short.

item.title: The Trials of Cobian
item.description: According to her friends, Tziporaâ€™s contemporary afflictions were tragic. Her medical problems; her violent childhood; her sensitivity and melancholy â€” you could feel sorry for her, because a lot of her problems were not her fault. She invoked sympathy. Tzipora never considered herself particularly tragic. It seemed straightforward, if difficult; she continued to live â€” and so she lived. Tzipora’s sympathy was instead reserved for her first and closest friend: Cobian.
